issue.title: assertThrows doesn't fail if the thrown exception is of child type

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ✅ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Steps to reproduce

`assertThrows(IOException.class, () -> service.readFile("sampleFile.txt")); `

this assertion will pass even if the exception is FileNotFoundException.

I believe this is happening because we are using `Class#isInstance` it will return true for parent types also.

https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/637a78393194737e77d6f9681ad93e9ddac1f399/junit-jupiter-api/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/api/AssertThrows.java#L58

Shouldn't this be replaced with `if (expectedType == actualException.getClass())` ?

body: Tentatively slated for 5.8 M1 for _team discussion_

As a "workaround", you could add another assertion to your test:
```java
Class<?> klass = assertThrows(RuntimeException.class, () -> reThrowSpecificException(404)).getClass();
assertTrue(klass.equals(RuntimeException.class));
```
because `assertThrows` returns the exception thrown.

It looks redundant but it gets the job done (until `assertThrowsExactly` gets added?).

(I'd also suggest AssertJ as an alternative option, but the issue seems to be focused on JUnit's own assertions.)

@Michael1993 I am already using this workaround in my code (https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2505#issuecomment-751446470), it is nice to have this assertion though as Assertj `assertThatThrownBy(..).isInstanceOf(..)` won't be useful either.
Sorry, what version of AssertJ are you using? AssertJ offers `assertThatThrownBy(..).isExactlyInstanceOf(..)` - but I don't know since when...

issue.title: Introduce assertThrowsExactly() in Jupiter assertions

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ✅ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

body: @sbrannen Oh, I'm so sorry. I didn't notice that. I'll be more watchful next time.
